newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast prods flatten late on sparse buying.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast prods flatten late on sparse buying.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices were mostly unchanged late as buyers continued to avoid a market propped up by NYMEX energy futures, they said.
"It's a little confused with a very strong NYMEX as backdrop," one broker said.
West Coast fundamentals remained mixed, with meager supply offset by even weaker demand.
"Low inventories don't help you unless you have something to drive it up," the broker said.
West Coast stocks fell last week by 709,000 barrels to hit 26.9 million, the American Petroleum Institute (API) said.
Traders called those volumes extremely low.
But demand has eased for gasoline, brokers said, curbing tight supply and the sharp rises in Wednesday's futures market -- which saw October heating oil up 2.28 cents a gallon to 67.87 cents.
Futures prices received a lift after Tuesday's API report indicated meager builds in U.S. distillate stocks, already at historic lows.

In the West, falling gasoline supplies and below-average refinery output come right before a period of heavy refinery maintenance, poising products for possible upswings should unplanned outages occur.
Meanwhile, Ultramar denied rumours on Wednesday that the hydrotreater shut at its 100,000 barrel-per-day refinery in Wilmington, California
A company spokeswoman said the plant was running short of hydrogen this week because an outside supplier had cut shipments due to production problems.
One trader said a lack of hydrogen could eventually hamper production from the plant's fluid catalytic cracker, which needs the gas.
Conventional or "clear" grade gasoline in Los Angeles remained 67/68 cents after falling 2.50 cents a gallon early.

Premium conventional in L.A. was nine cents over regular. The grade remained strong following a fire in early September at Mobil's Torrance, California, reformer -- a unit which turns low grade into high-grade gasoline.
Ultra-clean CARB gasoline in L.A. gave back early gains by slipping a cent to 72.50/73 cents a gallon.
Deals for October and September cost nearly the same, as business shifted to the later month.
Bids for low-sulphur diesel in L.A. paused after their morning downturn, staying 71 cents, while offers remained 72.50 cents. CARB grade also flattened out at 76/77.50 cents.
But traders say distillates might still soften, with cargoes expected soon.
Jet fuel prices slipped when a deal got done at 74.50 cents a gallon, 2.50 cents below Wednesday's early levels.
--David Brinkerhoff, Los Angeles bureau +1 213 380 2014
